content: In our various publication tooling, we've defined a number of extensions to handle edge cases, custom behaviour, and cross-version stuff. . Here's a list:

• http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/profile-spreadsheet
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/logical-spreadsheet
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/conceptmap-source-cardinality
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/conceptmap-source-name
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/conceptmap-source-type
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/conceptmap-target-cardinality
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/conceptmap-target-type
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/igpublisher-spreadsheet
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/logical-mapping-prefix
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/logical-mapping-suffix
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/resource-information
  • http://hl7.org/fhir/tools/StructureDefinition/ig-parameter
I think it's past time that we defined these formally. The natural way to do this is via a FHIR IG published at http://hl7.org/fhir/tools. Would this be a formal IG that FMG needs to approve?

I think the biggest question would be the change management process. If any of these are something external apps might make use of, we need to have a managed change process. If they're only for tools maintained by HL7 itself, I think we can be more lax.
Sounds that it might be safer to follow the process. Introducing exceptions is always tricky...
